title: U.S. News: U.S. Pulls Out of Emergent Contract
text:
A U.S. Department of Health and Human Services division initially awarded Emergent a contract in 2012 to complete construction of a manufacturing plant in Baltimore that would make drugs and vaccines to be used in a pandemic or other public-health emergency.

The contract was issued under a program called the Centers for Innovation in Advanced Development and Manufacturing, or CIADM. The contract's initial term was eight years, with options to extend the pact to 25 years.

When the coronavirus pandemic hit in 2020, the U.S. government reserved capacity at Emergent for the manufacture of Covid-19 vaccines and treatments.

But Emergent encountered contamination problems at the Baltimore plant that ruined batches of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Johnson & Johnson earlier this year, constraining the initial supply of doses.

Emergent shares dropped 37%, or $19.50, to $33.11 in trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange .
